org.orgName: United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE PETITION OF FRANCIS STEPHEB Medcraf FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.} No. 3038 Petition.
That he is forty- (40) years of age and has declared his intention to become a citizen of the United States.

That your petitioner is unlawfully imprisoned, detained, confined and restrained of his liberty by ROBERT T. HODGE, who is the Sheriff of and for ---------, King County, Washington, at Seattle in said state in this district.
That the said imprisonment, detention, confinement and restraint are illegal and that the illegality thereof consists in this, to- wit:

That on the 18th day of May A.D. 1915, one H.F. Conover did make and file in writing, under oath, a complaint before Justice Reah M. Whitehead who was then and still is a Justice of the Peace in the State of Washington in and for Seattle Precinct in the County of King, which said complaint charged this petitioner with having on the third day of May 1915 committed the crime of "practicing dentistry without a certificate as followsL:

He, said John Doe Medcraf" (meaning this petitioner) "in the county of King, state of Washington, on the 3rd day of May, 1915, did then and there willfully and unlawfully practice dentistry and did then and there treat diseases and lesions of the human teeth and jaws of said H.F. Conover, H.F. Conover then and there being a human being, and did then and there receive from H.F. Conover, in payment therefor, the sum of two dollars ($2), without
having first filed for record and having recorded in the office of the Auditor of the county wherein he then and there practiced, to wit, in the office of the Auditor of King County, State of Washington, a certificate from the Board of Dental Examiners of the State of Washington, authorizing him to so practice provided by law, contrary to the form of the stature in such case made and provided, and against the peace and dignity of the State of Washington. (Signed) H. F. Conover Subscribed and sworn to before me this 18th day of May 1915 (Signed) Reah M. Whitehead Justice of the Peace, Seattle Precinct, King County, Washington."

That thereupon the 21st day of May the said Reah M. Whitehead as such Justice of the Peace, issued a warrant in the name of the State of Washington in words and figures as follows:- "WARRANT OF ARREST"
STATE OF WASHINGTON COUNTY OF KING} SS IN JUSTICE COURT, SEATTLE PRECINCT
To the Sheriff or Any Constable of Said County:

Whereas H. F. Conover has this day complained in writing, under oath, to the undersigned one of the Justices of the Peace in and for said County, that on the 3rd day of May 1915 in said County and State, John Doe Medcraf did commit the crime of Practicing dentistry without a certificate.
Therefore, in the name of the State of Washington, you are commanded forthwith to apprehend the said John Doe Medraf and bring him before me to be dealt with according to law.
Given under my hand this 21st day of May 1915. (Signed) Reah M. Whitehead Justice of the Peace."

And thereupon on that day your petitioner was arested by authority of said warrant, by Edward Shrewsbury, a constable, and taken before said Justice of the Peace who thereupon required him to give bail for his appearance to answer to said charge on the 3rd day of June 1915 at 1-30 o'clock P?M. and to stand committed to the county jail in default of such bail. That petitioner ghave such bail and on said date his trial wasn't continued until June 9th 1915 at 1-30 o'clock P.M. at which time he duly appeared before said Justice and moved to quash said writ and discharge petitioner upon the grounds and all thereof hereinafter stated;- towit, the unconstitutionality of the statutes of the State of Washington hereinafter set forth as hereinafter specificied. Said motions being denied, the Court holding said laws to be valid and constitutional, received evidence and all the facts hereinafter recited were fully shown. Thereupon the said court found petitioner guilty as charged and adjudged him to pay a fine of $ and to stand committed until such fine be paid, to the County Jail of King County not exceeding 20 days and thereupon issued the warrant of commitment in pursuance of said judgement and your petitioner is now in custody thereunder and is so detained by the Sheriff of King County, Washington in the said jail, in virtue of said commitment.

Petitioner further shows that siad charge is based upon the facts recited in said warrant and complaint hereinbefore set forth and upon the Statutes of the State of Washington, viz; sections 8412 to 8425 respectively inclusive of Remington & Ballingers Cosed and Statutes of Washington (Annotated) whish are as follows;

"8416. (3025*) Examinations- Certificate. Any person or persons seeking to practice dentistry in the state of Washington, or to (own), operate or cause to be operated, (or to run or manage) a dental office or place for the practice of dentistry in the state of Washington after the passage of this act shall file his or her name, together with an application for examination, with the secretary of the state board of dental examiners, and at the time of making such application shall pay to the secretary of the board as a fee of twenty- five dollars. and to present him or herself at the first regular meeting thereafter of said board to undergo examination before that body. No person shall be eligible for such an exmaination unless he or she shall be of good moral character and shall present to said board his or her diploma from some dental college in good standing and shall give satisfactory evidence of his or her rightful possession of the same: Provided, this section shall not apply to persons engaged in the practice of dentistry at the same time of the passage of this act who are bona fide citizens of the state of Washington. All persons successfully passing such examination shall be reigstered as licensed dentists in the board register as hereinafter provided, and also receive a certificate, said certificate to be signed by the president and secretary of said board and in the following to- wit

This is yo certify that ______ is hereby licensed to practice dentistry in the state of Washington. This certificate must be filed for record in the office of the auditor of any county in which the party holding such certificate desires to practice, and it is unlawful for him (or her) to practice dentistry in any county in which said certificate is not filed for record.
Dated at ______this______day of ______, A.D. 190_.
__________ (President of said board of examiners.) (Secretary of said board.)

"8417. (3026) Certificate to be Recorded. The certificates in this chapter provided for shall entitle the holder thereof to practice dentistry in any county in the state of Washington: Provided, such certificate shall first be filed for record in the office of the auditor of the county in which such holder desires to practice, and nothing herein contained shall be construed to permit any holder of any certificate to practice in any county in this state unless such certificate shall have been first recorded in the office of the auditor of such county as herein provided: Provided further, that any such holder of a certificate may practice in more than one or any number of counties in this state on having such certificate recorded in each of such counties in which such holder desires to so practice. Said board of dental examiners shall, upon satisfactory proof of the loss of any certificate issued under the provisions of this chapter, issue a new certificate in place thereof. Any person failing to pass the first examination successfully may demand a second examination at the subsequent meeting of a said board, and no fee shall be charged to (for) said examination: Provided, that the second examination is taken before the expiration of one year. (L. '93, p.91, Section 5.)"

"8420. (3028) Auditor's Record. The county auditor of each county is required to record, in a special book to be kept by him for that purpose, all certificates issued under the provision of this chapter which may be presented to him for that purpose. After the record of any such certificate, such auditor shall return to the same with a certificate of its record to the party entitled to the same. Said auditor shall receive for such filing and record a fee of one dollar. (L. '93, p.92, Section 7.)"

"8421. (3029*) Penalty. Any person who, as principal, agent, employer, employee or assistant, who in any manner whatsoever shall practice dentistry or who shall (own, run,) operate or cause to be operated, (or manage) a dental office or headquarters in the state of Washington without having first filed for record and has recorded in the office of the auditor of the county wherein he shall so practice or do such act, a certificate from said board of dental examiners as herein provided, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be fined in any sum not less than fifty dollars, nor more than two hundred dollars, or be confined for any period not exceeding six months in the county jail for each and every offense; Provided, the foregoing provisions of this section shall not, prior to the tenth day of July, 1901, aplly to any person who shall be practicing dentistry in this state at the time of the passage of this act and whose name shall be registered under the provisions of this act in the records of said board. After said tenth day of July, 1901, all the provisions of this section shall apply to all persons whomsoever. All fine recovered under this act shall be paid into the common school fund of the county in which the conviction is had."

"8424. (3032*) Practicing Dentistry Defined. All person shall be said to be practicing dentistry within the meaning of this chapter who shall contrary to this act for a fee or salary or other reward paid either to himself or to another person for operations or parts of operations of any kind, treat diseases or lesions of the human teeth or of jaws or correct malpositions
thereof, (or who shall own, run or manage a dental office or department) in the state of Washington, without registering and procuring the license as herein provided."

Petitioner further says that said law, and in particular the sections quoted, aforesaid, are void and of no effect, and contravene the provisions of Section 1, Article 14 of the amendments to said constitution, in that they deprive your petitioner of his liberty and property without due process of law, and deny to your petitioner the equal protection of the laws.

Petitioner says further that the said law is in contravention of the provisions of Article 5 of the amendments of the constitution of the United States, in that it deprives your petitioner of his liberty and property without due process of law.

Petitioner further sayd that the said law is in contravention of the constitution of the state of Washington, to-wit: Section 12 of Article 1 thereof because the same grants privileges and immunities to certain citizens and classes of citizens, which upon the same terms shall not equally belong to all citizens.

Petitioner further shows that the same is in contravention of Section 7, Article 1 of the constitution of the state of Washington in that the same distrubs petitioner in his private affairs without authorit of law, and that the same is in contravention of Section 3 of Article 1 of the constitution of the state of Washington in that it deprives the petitioner of his liberty and property without due process of law.

Your petitioner further shows that at the age of thirteen years, being then a resident of London, England, he was regularly apprenticed to Wm. Lombardi, L.D.S, a practicing dentist, member of Royal College of Dental Surgeons of England, at 17 Grand Marlborough Street, London, W.C., England. That he entered such apprenticeship
on the 6th of August 1888 and thereafter continued to act and serve said master as apprentice in his said business of dentistry and dental surgery for five years, being the full term of his apprenticeship.

That on September 8, 1893, after serving such apprenticeship, petitioner removed to Athens, Greece where he worked as dental assistant to Mr. Coracatsanis, Surgeon Dentist, who was the leading dentist of Athens, and continued so to work for two years as dental mechanic in the regular study and practice of that profession.

That in the fall of 1895 petitioner returned to London and entered again the office of Wm. Lombardi, aforesaid, for further study and there prosecuted such study in dental surgery for six months under said dentist.

That in 1896 petitioner was engaged in the office of Dr. Waldo Royce, dentist at Tunbridge Wells, England, said Dr. Royce being a graduate of Harvard University, U.S.A., where petitioners remained and practiced for eight months as general dental assistant.

In December 1896 petitioner moved to Cannes, France where he was emploted by Mr. Jas. Shillcock, L.D.S., Member Royal College of Dental Surgeons, and was employed in charge of the office of said dentist for five months.
In June 1897 petitioner returned to the office of Wm. Lombardi where he studied and practiced dental surgery for five months.
In December 1897 petitioner was employed by Dr. Edwin Shillcock, L.D.S., at Nice, France, as general assistant and continued in that practice for a term of six months.
In July 1898 petitioner was employed in a dental office at Mile End Road, London, England for four months as dental mechanic.

In November 1898 petitioner returned to Mr. Edwin Shillcock, L.D.S., at Nice, France and was by him employed for seven months in
the practice of general detnal work.

In June 1899 petitioner was employed in the office of Dr. Isador Clifford in London, England and continued there for a period of four months as chief dental mechanic. Said Dr. Clifford had a very large practice in dentistry and treated as dentist, the then Prince of Wales, who is now the King of England.
That in December 1900 petitioner aggain was employed by Mr. Edwin Shillcock at Nice, France, as operating assistant and continued there as such for seven months.
In July 1901 petitioner returned to London and opened an office for himself as dentist on High Street, Plumstead, London, S.E. where he continued the practice of dentistry for two years.
In April 1903 an account of ill health petitioner removed to Canada and made his home at Lethbridge, Alberta for five years where he continued to practice his profession as dentist.

That in Febrauary 1908 petitioner moved to Seattle, Washington and declaring his intention to become a citizen of the United States he opened an office as dentist at East 72d Street, Greenlake, Seattle where he has continued the practice od dentistry undisturbed until the issue of the warrant of arrest herein complained of.

That immediately upon opening his said office and before beginning the practice of dentistry at Seattle, aforesaid, your petitioner duly applied to the State Board of Dentistry of the state of Washington for license to practice dentistry, tendered the legal fee and offered himself for examination, pursuant to law, and in all things complied with the requirements of the statutes in such case made and provided, save only, that he did not present any diploma from any college of dentistry whatever for the reason that he did not possess one and does not now possess any, having obtained his possession, learning and skill at the places, by the practice and study and in
the matter hereinbefore set forth.

That for the reason that he did not and could not present any such diploma the said State Board of Dentistry Examiners refused to receive the application of petitioner of a license, refused to examine him as to his qualifications to practice dentistry and refused to grant him any license therefor.

Petitioner further shows that he is and at all times has been ready and willing to submit to examination by any duly constituted authority as to his qualifications to practice dentistry and is willing to pay the fees provided by law and otherwise comply with all the provisions of law and with all reasonable requirements, save the presetnation of a diploma aforesaid.

That in order to obtain such diploma it would be necessary that petitioner attend some dental college for at least three years; that no such college exists in the state of Washington, or ever has existed in this state, and that your petitioner is unable for want of financial means to sustain himself and his family during the time that would be required to go to some other state and attend such college and obtain such diploma, and that were he to take that course he would learn nothing more than he alread knows, would acquire no other or further skill than he already possess and would be no better qualified in point of fact to practice his profession than he now is.

Petitioner further says that he is fully qualified by experience, study and practice to perform all the operations incident to his profession with skill and according to the best standards to practice in that profession. That he always has and still does read and study arduously in all the matters and things pertaining to his profession and keeps himself fully up to the best and most modern standards in the practice of dentistry and dental surgery. That he
maintains and has ever maintained in Seattle during his practice there, one of the best equipped dental offices in the city and has a large clientele of patients and customers, not one of whom has ever complained of any inattention, want of skill or otherwise in the course of his practice here.

That your petitioner possesses and will present to your Honor the highest recommendations as to moral character and professional skill from those with whom he has been employed. That your petitioner is a man of family and of good character and in every way qualified to practice the profession of dentistry aforesaid.

Your petitioner further shows that H. F. Conover the complainant who caused his arrest, was employed by the State Dental Board to obtain information and to solicit and induce your petitioner to perform upon him an operation in dental surgery, to- wit: the removing of two decayed teeth, for the express purpose of causing petitioner's arrest therefor, and not for any honest purpose in promoting the public health, morals or safety.

Petitioner further shows that there are many dentists now practicing as such in the state of Washingon who were so practicing and were residents of the state in the year 1901, at the time of the passage of the law above quoted, who never have been examined by the state board nor possessed any diploma from any dental college.

Petitioner further shows that the Supreme Court of the state of Washington has declared the said law herein quoted to be not violative of the state or federal constitution in the particulars herein set forth, and that unless this honorable court defends and preserves the rights of your petitioner under the constitution of the United States and of the state of Washington, petitioner will be further restrained of his liberty and deprived of his property pursuant to said void unconstitutional law and in violation of the constitution of the United States in the particulars as
aforesaid.

WHEREFORE your petitioner prays that a Writ of Habeas Corpus be granted, directed to the said Robert Hodge as Sheriff of King Cou County, Washington, commanding him to have the body of your petitioner Francis Stephen Medcraf before Your Honor at the time and place therein to be specified, to do and receive what shall then and there be determined and considered by Your Honor concerning him, together with the time and cause of petitioner's detention and said Writ; and that petitioner may be restored to his liberty. Dated June 11th, 1915. Francis Stephen Medcraf.
STATE OF WASHINGTON SS COUNTY OF KING

FRANCIS STEPHEN MEDCRAF being first duly sworn, and oath says; that he is the petitioner named in the foregoing petition; that he has carefully read the same and knows the contents thereof and that the same is true of his own knowledge save as to the matters therein stated on information and belief and as to such matters he believes it to be true. Francis Stephen Medcraf.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 11th day of June A.D. 1915. Geo D. Emery Notary Public for Washington Residing at Seattle.
